update.description:
This PR tries to provide an initial implementation for the task "Make a generic docker container based simulation instance": https://bitbucket.org/osrf/cloudsim/issues/5/make-a-generic-docker-container-based.
It also later added new images for running the SRC simulator.

As part of the work, the official gazebo7 (stable) image was extended to provide support to nvidia-docker-plugin and have the gazebo models already downloaded in the container as well as a cloudsim user (different than root). 

The PR also brings a new images based on the previous ones. Specifically: new image name nvidia-gazebo-ros, which is an extension of the nvidia-gazebo that also includes ROS indigo. Also created a "src-cloudim" image which extends from the previous one and provides support for runninng the SRC simulator.
 
There are build and run scripts as well. The run_container script is based on the existent src_cloud_simulator repo's run_simulator script, but with small changes to allow for image names as arguments.
update.title: Initial SRC cloudsim gazebo docker container

pull_request.title: Initial SRC cloudsim gazebo docker container

content.raw: Oops, It was non-sudo before, but I recommended @preyna change it because the default docker installation requires sudo to run.

content.raw: I added my user account to the `docker` group so I don't have to use `sudo` ([docker docs](https://docs.docker.com/engine/installation/linux/linux-postinstall/)). Perhaps we could make this a non-sudo command? People could still invoke this script with sudo if they don't want to modify the user groups.
content.html: I added my user account to the docker group so I don't have to use sudo (docker docs). Perhaps we could make this a non-sudo command? People could still invoke this script with sudo if they don't want to modify the user groups.

content.raw:
This looks good to me for creating an image for the simulator container.


Chatting with @scpeters the field container image probably just needs ros-indigo-ros-core with ihmc_msgs installed. The competitors would use that image as a base to install their code. I don't think that's relevant to this PR though.
content.html:
This looks good to me for creating an image for the simulator container.

Chatting with @scpeters the field container image probably just needs ros-indigo-ros-core with ihmc_msgs installed. The competitors would use that image as a base to install their code. I don't think that's relevant to this PR though.

content.raw: It's possible the run script will have to pass this in as an environment variable. The simulator container will have to communicate with the Field Computer container without having access the internet. I think this means the two will be on a docker network together, and the ROS_IP may have to be the simulator container's address on that network.
content.html: It's possible the run script will have to pass this in as an environment variable. The simulator container will have to communicate with the Field Computer container without having access the internet. I think this means the two will be on a docker network together, and the ROS_IP may have to be the simulator container's address on that network.

update.description:
This PR tries to provide an initial implementation for the task "Make a generic docker container based simulation instance": https://bitbucket.org/osrf/cloudsim/issues/5/make-a-generic-docker-container-based.
It also later added new images for running the SRC simulator.

As part of the work, the official gazebo7 (stable) image was extended to provide support to nvidia-docker-plugin and have the gazebo models already downloaded in the container as well as a cloudsim user (different than root).

Also created a "src-cloudim" image which extends from the previous one and provides support for runninng the SRC simulator.

pull_request.title: Initial SRC cloudsim gazebo docker container

update.description:
This PR tries to provide an initial implementation for the task "Make a generic docker container based simulation instance": https://bitbucket.org/osrf/cloudsim/issues/5/make-a-generic-docker-container-based.

As part of the work, a the official gazebo7 (stable) image was extended, to provide support to nvidia-docker-plugin and have the gazebo models already downloaded in the container as well as a gazebo user (different than root). 
The provided dockerfiles were split in 2: the models+user image , and the nvidia-docker-plugin one. This separation was made to allow for different potential "video driver installed in image" extensions (i.e. the non nvidia-docker-plugin way).    

There are build and run scripts as well. The run-gazebo-container script is based on the existent run_simulator script, but with small changes to allow for image names as arguments.

I've tested this in my local machines (with and without nvida), and a small test in an AWS instance.
update.title: Initial cloudsim gazebo docker container

There are build and run scripts as well. The run-gazebo-container script is based on the existent run_simulator script, but with small changes to allow for image names as arguments.

I've tested this in my local machines (with and without nvida), and a small test in an AWS instance.

content.raw: Thanks Shane! I tried that. What I noticed is that switching here to using nvidia-docker wrapper CLI makes this image only work with a host that do actually have NVIDIA drivers installed. The other alternative (using nvidia-docker-plugin REST) allows for non-nvidia hosts to use the gazebo image too (e.g. my current machine). That's why I kept that way. Please let me know if you want me to change it
content.html: Thanks Shane! I tried that. What I noticed is that switching here to using nvidia-docker wrapper CLI makes this image only work with a host that do actually have NVIDIA drivers installed. The other alternative (using nvidia-docker-plugin REST) allows for non-nvidia hosts to use the gazebo image too (e.g. my current machine). That's why I kept that way. Please let me know if you want me to change it

content.raw:
I tried to do that, but for some reason (even in my host machine) the extract fails if we use z flag. 
I copied this snippet from the other script, and the z flag wasn't present in the original script. Maybe the gazebo models file was not compressed gzipped?
content.html: I tried to do that, but for some reason (even in my host machine) the extract fails if we use z flag. I copied this snippet from the other script, and the z flag wasn't present in the original script. Maybe the gazebo models file was not compressed gzipped?

content.raw: I think these lines only work if the script is called from a shell in the docker folder. Adding `DIR="$( cd "$( dirname "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}" )" && pwd )"` and changing these lines to something like `docker build ${DOCKER_ARGS} -t gazebo-cloudsim:latest $DIR/gazebo-cloudsim` would allow the script to be called from a terminal in any folder.
content.html: I think these lines only work if the script is called from a shell in the docker folder. Adding DIR="$( cd "$( dirname "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}" )" && pwd )" and changing these lines to something like docker build ${DOCKER_ARGS} -t gazebo-cloudsim:latest $DIR/gazebo-cloudsim would allow the script to be called from a terminal in any folder.

pullrequest.title: Initial SRC cloudsim gazebo docker container

content.raw: I think this should be prefixed with `sudo`. After installation docker requires a root user to run it. A user can add themselves to the docker group, but they may not want to do so because it effectively gives their account root access to the system through the docker socket.
content.html: I think this should be prefixed with sudo. After installation docker requires a root user to run it. A user can add themselves to the docker group, but they may not want to do so because it effectively gives their account root access to the system through the docker socket.

content.raw: I noticed the examples in the nvidia-docker documentation now use the command "nvidia-docker" Instead of describing how to fetch the docker params. It could be a signal that using "nvidia-docker" instead of "docker" will be more stable long term.
content.html: I noticed the examples in the nvidia-docker documentation now use the command "nvidia-docker" Instead of describing how to fetch the docker params. It could be a signal that using "nvidia-docker" instead of "docker" will be more stable long term.

update.description:
This PR tries to provide an initial implementation for the task "Make a generic docker container based simulation instance": https://bitbucket.org/osrf/cloudsim/issues/5/make-a-generic-docker-container-based.

As part of the work, a the official gazebo7 (stable) image was extended, to provide support to nvidia-docker-plugin and have the gazebo models already downloaded in the container as well as a gazebo user (different than root). 
The provided dockerfiles were split in 2: the models+user image , and the nvidia-docker-plugin one. This separation was made to allow for different potential "video driver installed in image" extensions (i.e. the non nvidia-docker-plugin way).    

There are build and run scripts as well. The run-gazebo-container script is based on the existent run_simulator script, but with small changes to allow for image names as arguments.

I've tested this in my local machines (with and without nvida), and a small test in an AWS instance.
